case_name: Criminal Appeal No.151 of 1997 and Criminal Appeal No.227 of 1997

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 151 of 1997 and Criminal Appeal No. 227 of 1997 were filed by special leave challenging the High Court judgment upholding conviction under Section 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: With Criminal Appeal No.227 of 1997 K. Sabharwal, J. These appeals by special leave challenge the judgment of the High Court by which the companyviction of the appellants for offence under Section 201 of the Indian Penal Code has been upheld.

facts.text: Appellants in Criminal Appeal No. 151 of 1997 are family members of Baldev Singh: Nos. 3 and 5 brothers, No. 4 wife of No. 3, No. 6 wife of No. 5, No. 7 sister, No. 2 father who died.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in Criminal Appeal No.151 of 1997 are family members of Baldev Singh. Appellant Nos. 3 and 5 are brothers of Baldev Singh and appellant No.4 is wife of appellant No.3 whereas appellant No.6 is wife of appellant No.5. Appellant No.7 is sister of Baldev Singh. Baldev Singh is son of appellant No.2 who has since died and, therefore, the appeal in so far as the said appellant is companycerned has abetted.

facts.text: Harjap Singh is the sole appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 227 of 1997 and is a family friend of Baldev Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The sole appellant, Harjap Singh, in Criminal Appellant No.227 is family friend of Baldev Singh.

facts.text: Baldev Singh married Manmohan Kaur in 1979.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution in brief is as under Baldev Singh was married with Manmohan Kaur in the year 1979.

facts.text: Baldev Singh harassed Manmohan Kaur for bringing insufficient dowry.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that Baldev Singh was harassing Manmohan Kaur for number bringing sufficient amount of dowry.

facts.text: On 21 June 1985, Manmohan Kaur visited her father's house in village Nangal Thindal and complained about dowry demand of Rs. 30,000.

anchor.surface_text: She visited house of her father in village Nangal Thindal on 21st June, 1985 and told him that a demand of Rs.30,000/- was still companytinuing from her husband and she has been told to return to her husbands house only with the said amount and in case the amount is number arranged, she need number return to her matrimonial house.

facts.text: Manmohan Kaur left her three-year-old daughter at her parents' house on 21 June 1985.

anchor.surface_text: Her father, PW4  Harbans Singh , however, sent back his daughter to her matrimonial house with assurance that he would soon visit the house of her in-laws and settle the matter there. Manmohan Kaur left behind her three years old daughter at her parents house.

facts.text: Harbans Singh sent Manmohan Kaur back to matrimonial home with assurance to settle dowry issue.

anchor.surface_text: Her father, PW4  Harbans Singh , however, sent back his daughter to her matrimonial house with assurance that he would soon visit the house of her in-laws and settle the matter there.

facts.text: On 22 June 1985 at about 2:35 p.m., Baldev Singh informed Harbans Singh that Manmohan Kaur was missing since early morning.

anchor.surface_text: On 22nd June at about 2.35 p.m., Baldev Singh came to the house of his father-in-law and informed him that Manmohan Kaur was missing from the house since early morning that day.

facts.text: Harbans Singh informed Baldev Singh about the dowry harassment complaint and asked him to search for Manmohan Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: Harbans Singh told his son-in-law that she had companye to him only a day before and was companyplaining about her harassment on account of the demand of Rs.30,000/- made by him, his parents, sisters, sisters-in-law and brothers as dowry and asked his son-in-law to have a thorough search of Manmohan Kaur.

facts.text: Harbans Singh searched for his daughter but failed, and on 23 June 1985 learnt that her dead body was traced by in-laws.

anchor.surface_text: Harbans Singh also asked his son-in-law to send information to him immediately when she is found and on his own he went out along with his relatives to search his daughter. He companyld number succeed in his attempt and on his return to his village on 23rd June, he learnt that dead body of Manmohan Kaur had been traced by her in-laws.

facts.text: On 23 June 1985, Harbans Singh saw Manmohan Kaur's dead body being cremated at the cremation ground by in-laws.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately, Harbans Singh rushed to the house of the in-laws of Manmohan Kaur. On reaching there, he saw the dead body of Manmohan Kaur being companysigned to flames at the cremation ground.

facts.text: In-laws told Harbans Singh they cremated the body after informing police, completing formalities, as it was decomposing.

anchor.surface_text: On enquiry from Baldev Singh and his parents as to why they did number wait for his arrival, Harbans Singh was told that dead body was cremated by them after informing the Police and after companypleting the necessary formalities and also that it was getting decomposed and they companyld number have waited any longer for his arrival for cremation.

facts.text: On 24 June 1985, Harbans Singh filed written application Exhibit PD to SSP Hoshiarpur suspecting murder by in-laws for dowry.

anchor.surface_text: On 24th June, Harbans Singh filed a written application  Exhibit PD  with the Senior Superintendent of Police, Hoshiarpur expressing his doubt that his daughter has been murdered by her in-laws for number bringing sufficient dowry.

facts.text: Complaint endorsed to SHO on 4 July 1985 to register under Section 306 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It was mentioned therein that he was suspecting the appellants besides Baldev Singh and his father. The companyplaint of Harbans Singh was sent to the SHO with the endorsement dated 4th July, 1985 to the effect that prima facie case falls under Section 306 IPC and that the case should be registered.

facts.text: Formal FIR under Section 306 IPC registered on 4 July 1985.

anchor.surface_text: The formal FIR under Section 306 was registered on 4th July and investigation companyducted whereafter challan was filed and case companymitted by Magistrate to Court of Sessions for trial under Section 306/201 IPC.

facts.text: Harbans Singh filed criminal complaint under Sections 302/201/149 IPC, consolidated with police case.

anchor.surface_text: Harbans Singh, number satisfied with the investigation, also filed a criminal companyplaint against the appellants and others under Section 302/201/149 IPC. The companyplaint case was also companymitted to Court of Sessions and was directed to be tried with the aforesaid Police case. Both the cases were companysolidated.

facts.text: Sessions Court acquitted all accused under Section 302 and 302/149 IPC; convicted Baldev under 306, appellants under 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Court acquitted all the accused of offence under Section 302 as also of offence under Section 302/149 IPC. For offence under Section 306, Baldev Singh was held guilty. The appellants were acquitted of charge under Section 306. They were, however, found guilty of offence punishable under Section 201 IPC and Rigorous Imprisonment for one year was imposed on each of them besides fine.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeals, confirmed acquittal under 306 and conviction under 201 for appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal filed by the State and also by Harbans Singh challenging judgment of acquittal and the appeal filed by the appellants challenging their companyviction for offence under Section 201 were disposed of by impugned companymon judgment of the High Court. All the appeals have been dismissed.

facts.text: No autopsy was conducted on Manmohan Kaur's dead body.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Court has found that when Harbans Singh with PW8  Darshan Singh  reached the cremation ground, pyre of Manmohan Kaur was burning and all the accused along with many other persons were present there and according to the accused persons, dead body was in their house before it was taken to the cremation ground and cremated and also that numberautopsy on the dead body of Manmohan Kaur was companyducted.

facts.text: Body was cremated in haste without informing parents and police.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings only, the companyclusion reached by the Sessions Court is that the body was cremated in a haste without informing the parents of the deceased and the Police and these circumstances indicate that all the accused persons being close relations and being in the same house had the knowledge or were having reasons to believe that offence in relation to the death of Manmohan Kaur had been companymitted

facts.text: All accused were present at the cremation ground.

anchor.surface_text: from the statement of Harbans Singh  PW4 , Kulwaran Singh  PW5  and Darshan Singh  PW8 , it appears that all the accused were present at the cremation ground when dead body of Manmohan Kaur was cremated

facts.text: Supreme Court found no evidence that appellants knew or had reason to believe an offence was committed and caused evidence to disappear.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence to prove the guilt of the appellants for offence under Section 201 IPC. It cannot be held that the appellants knew or had reason to believe that offence had been companymitted and participated in cremation to companyceal and dispose of the dead body.

issues.text: The sole issue that remains to be examined in these appeals is regarding the correctness of the conviction of the appellants for offence under Section 201 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The sole issue that remains to be examined in these appeals is regarding the correctness of the conviction of the appellants for offence under Section 201 IPC.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution proved that the appellants had knowledge or reason to believe that an offence under Section 306 IPC had been committed and that they caused the evidence to disappear with intent to screen the offender from legal punishment under Section 201 IPC

anchor.surface_text: For conviction under the said offence, the prosecution was required to prove that the appellants had knowledge or had reason to believe that an offence under Section 306 had been committed by Baldev Singh and with such knowledge or belief they caused evidence of commission of the offence to disappear either with the intention of screening the offender from legal punishment or with that intention gave any information respecting the offence which they knew or believed to be false.

issues.text: Whether mere presence at the house or cremation ground and family relationship with the offender is sufficient to attract liability under Section 201 IPC or give rise to presumption of knowledge of commission of offence

anchor.surface_text: The mere presence of the accused at the house or at the cremation ground or their relationship with her husband would not attract the provision of Section 201 IPC. Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship.

holdings.text: There is no evidence to prove the guilt of the appellants for offence under Section 201 IPC. It cannot be held that the appellants knew or had reason to believe that offence had been committed and participated in cremation to conceal and dispose of the dead body.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence to prove the guilt of the appellants for offence under Section 201 IPC. It cannot be held that the appellants knew or had reason to believe that offence had been committed and participated in cremation to conceal and dispose of the dead body.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After reviewing record, only findings are family ties and presence at cremation; insufficient to prove knowledge, belief of offence, or intent to screen offender.

holdings.text: The mere presence of the accused at the house or at the cremation ground or their relationship with her husband would not attract the provision of Section 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The mere presence of the accused at the house or at the cremation ground or their relationship with her husband would not attract the provision of Section 201 IPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence and relationship alone do not establish knowledge or reason to believe offence committed as required under Section 201 IPC.

holdings.text: Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship.

anchor.surface_text: Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No basis in law or evidence to presume knowledge merely from presence or family ties.

holdings.text: For conviction under Section 201 IPC, the prosecution was required to prove that the appellants had knowledge or had reason to believe that an offence under Section 306 had been committed by Baldev Singh and with such knowledge or belief they caused evidence of commission of the offence to disappear either with the intention of screening the offender from legal punishment or with that intention gave any information respecting the offence which they knew or believed to be false.

anchor.surface_text: For conviction under the said offence, the prosecution was required to prove that the appellants had knowledge or had reason to believe that an offence under Section 306 had been committed by Baldev Singh and with such knowledge or belief they caused evidence of commission of the offence to disappear either with the intention of screening the offender from legal punishment or with that intention gave any information respecting the offence which they knew or believed to be false.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elements of Section 201 IPC mandate proof of prior offence, accused's knowledge/belief thereof, and intentional disappearance of evidence to screen offender.

holdings.text: In order to establish the charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been committed; mere suspicion that it has been committed is not sufficient. It has to be proved that the accused knew or had reason to believe that such offence had been committed, and with the requisite knowledge and with the intent to screen the offender from legal punishment caused the evidence thereof to disappear or gave false information respecting such offence knowing or having reason to believe the same to be false.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Palvinder Kaur v. The State of Punjab (1953) 4 SCR 94 has held that in order to establish the charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been committed mere suspicion that it has been committed is not sufficient. It has to be proved that the accused knew or had reason to believe that such offence had been committed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent from Palvinder Kaur and subsequent cases, proof of offence and accused's mens rea required beyond suspicion.

precedents.citation: Palvinder Kaur v. The State of Punjab 1953 4 SCR 94

anchor.surface_text: Palvinder Kaur v. The State of Punjab 1953 4 SCR 94

precedents.case_name: Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: To establish charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been committed; mere suspicion is not sufficient. Accused knew or had reason to believe offence committed and caused evidence to disappear with intent to screen offender from legal punishment.
precedents.cited_holding: in order to establish the charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been committed mere suspicion that it has been committed is number sufficient. It has to be proved that the accused knew or had reason to believe that such offence had been committed, and with the requisite knowledge and with the intent to screen the offender from legal punishment caused the evidence thereof to disappear or gave false information respecting such offence knowing or having reason to believe the same to be false.

anchor.surface_text: The mere presence of the accused at the house or at the cremation ground or their relationship with her husband would number attract the provision of Section 201 IPC. Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship. There is noother finding except above noticed against the appellants. We have also perused the record. There is numberevidence to prove the guilt of the appellants for offence under Section 201 IPC. It cannot be held that the appellants knew or had reason to believe that offence had been companymitted and participated in cremation to conceal and dispose of the dead body. In absence of evidence, it cannot be assumed on suspicion alone that the appellants must have known or must have reason to believe that Baldev Singh abetted in companymission of offence and, by being present at the cremation ground, they caused the evidence of commission of the offence to disappear with intention to screen Baldev Singh from legal punishment. This Court in Palvinder Kaur v. The State of Punjab 1953 4 SCR 94 has held that in order to establish the charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been companymitted mere suspicion that it has been companymitted is number sufficient.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction of appellants under Section 201 IPC set aside for lack of evidence proving knowledge or reason to believe an offence was committed and intent to screen the offender

Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship. It cannot be held that the appellants knew or had reason to believe that offence had been companymitted and participated in cremation to conceal and dispose of the dead body. In absence of evidence, it cannot be assumed on suspicion alone that the appellants must have known or must have reason to believe that Baldev Singh abetted in companymission of offence and, by being present at the cremation ground, they caused the evidence of commission of the offence to disappear with intention to screen Baldev Singh from legal punishment. anchor.surface_text: For conviction under the said offence, the prosecution was required to prove that the appellants had knowledge or had reason to believe that an offence under Section 306 had been committed by Baldev Singh and with such knowledge or belief they caused evidence of commission of the offence to disappear either with the intention of screening the offender from legal punishment or with that intention gave any information respecting the offence which they knew or believed to be false.

The mere presence of the accused at the house or at the cremation ground or their relationship with her husband would number attract the provision of Section 201 IPC. Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship. There is noother finding except above noticed against the appellants. We have also perused the record. There is numberevidence to prove the guilt of the appellants for offence under Section 201 IPC. It cannot be held that the appellants knew or had reason to believe that offence had been companymitted and participated in cremation to conceal and dispose of the dead body. In absence of evidence, it cannot be assumed on suspicion alone that the appellants must have known or must have reason to believe that Baldev Singh abetted in companymission of offence and, by being present at the cremation ground, they caused the evidence of commission of the offence to disappear with intention to screen Baldev Singh from legal punishment. This Court in Palvinder Kaur v. The State of Punjab 1953 4 SCR 94 has held that in order to establish the charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been companymitted mere suspicion that it has been companymitted is number sufficient.

edges.explanation: The general requirement to prove an offence under Section 201 IPC in h5 supports the specific application to knowledge of Section 306 IPC offence in h4.
The holding emphasizes the necessity to prove commission of an offence for Section 201 IPC conviction beyond mere suspicion, addressing the issue concerning proof related to Section 306 IPC offence.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Palvinder Kaur v. The State of Punjab (1953) 4 SCR 94 has held that in order to establish the charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been committed mere suspicion that it has been committed is not sufficient. It has to be proved that the accused knew or had reason to believe that such offence had been committed,

The mere presence of the accused at the house or at the cremation ground or their relationship with her husband would number attract the provision of Section 201 IPC. Presumption that the appellants had the knowledge of commission of offence cannot be drawn from their mere presence at the house or cremation ground or on account of relationship. This Court in Palvinder Kaur v. The State of Punjab 1953 4 SCR 94 has held that in order to establish the charge under Section 201 IPC, it is essential to prove that an offence has been companymitted mere suspicion that it has been companymitted is number sufficient.
